verb.description: Reside or have one's place of business in (a building)
examples: the apartment she occupies in Manhattan

verb.description: Fill or preoccupy (the mind or thoughts)
examples: her mind was occupied with alarming questions

verb.description: Take control of (a place, especially a country) by military conquest or settlement.
examples: the region was occupied by Britain during World War I

origin: Middle English: formed irregularly from Old French occuper, from Latin occupare seize. A now obsolete vulgar sense have sexual relations with seems to have led to the general avoidance of the word in the 17th and most of the 18th century.
